title: How to Singe Paper

steps.headline: Choose a spot to work near the kitchen sink.
steps.description: This way you can drop the paper into the sink if the whole sheet suddenly catches fire. If you prefer to sit while you work, set up a large baking sheet on the table to catch the paper if you need to drop it. Keep a glass of water handy if you’re not working near a sink so that you can quickly douse any flames that get out of control.

steps.headline: Ventilate the room.
steps.description: Since you could potentially create strong fumes if you’re burning paper with any type of coating on it, open windows and doors to provide air flow while you work.

steps.headline: Supervise children.
steps.description: This is a fun activity for kids to participate in, but they should not do it without adult supervision. Explain some of the dangers involved, and instruct them to drop anything that starts burning out of control onto their baking sheet or other fire-proof surface.

steps.headline: Select a piece of uncoated paper.
steps.description: Any piece of paper that’s shiny or very bright white probably has a coating on it. This makes it more aesthetically pleasing for printing purposes, but makes it more difficult to achieve a natural, singed look. Choose a piece of paper that’s designed for painting, watercolors, or charcoal drawing and has fibers that you can clearly see.

steps.headline: Light a candle or turn on a lighter.
steps.description: Either can be used to the same effect, but don’t use anything more powerful, such as a butane torch. This will simply be too powerful a tool to use on paper.

steps.headline: Hold the paper beside the flame for singed edges.
steps.description: Slide the edge of the paper back and forth through the flame a few times until it’s glowing, but don’t let it actually catch fire.

steps.headline: Hold the paper above the flame if you want singed holes.
steps.description: Holding the paper about 1 inch (5 cm) above the flame, allow the heat from the candle to rise and burn a hole in your paper. Pull the paper up as soon as you see a hole starting to form, since it can spread quickly. Move the paper slightly closer if you’re not seeing any burning.

steps.headline: Douse the flame with water or by blowing on it.
steps.description: If you blow on it, be sure you’re not blowing embers toward anything flammable. It’s ok to sprinkle some water on it and then lay it flat to dry, since the water spots will contribute to an aged appearance.

methods.name: Using Lemon Juice and a Heat Gun

steps.headline: Place your paper on a heat-resistant surface.
steps.description: Use a baking sheet or a stone cutting board to hold the paper while you heat it. You won’t be using an open flame, but heat guns can reach very high temperatures so it’s important to still take safety precautions.

steps.headline: Rub the edges of the paper with lemon or lime juice.
steps.description: The more lemon juice you dab on, the greater the burn effect you’ll get later, so use as little or as much as you want. You can use the side of a lemon or lime slice to rub it in, or just squirt some of the juice onto the paper and use your finger to distribute it.

steps.headline: Hold a heat gun near the edge of the paper.
steps.description: Heat guns are relatively inexpensive and can be purchased at most craft or hardware stores. Always hold it at a 45-degree angle about 2-3 inches (5-7 cm) away from the edge of the paper. Since you’ll be blowing hot air at the paper, you may want to put on an oven mitt and hold down the opposite side of the paper with one hand.

steps.headline: Heat the paper until the edges begin to look burnt.
steps.description: The longer you heat one spot, the darker it will become. This process will not be as instantaneous as using an open flame, so be patient. Try moving the heat gun a little closer if you’re not getting the effect you want.
